1.verse: Paul Defends His Apostolate -Chapter 1 -Address -Paul Commissioned by Christ Himself. -Paul, an apostle—commissioned not by human authority or by any human being, but by Jesus Christ and God the Father who raised him from the dead—

2.verse: and all the brethren who are with me, to the Churches of Galatia.

3.verse: Grace to you and peace from God our Father and the Lord Jesus Christ,

4.verse: who gave himself for our sins to deliver us from the present evil age in accordance with the will of our God and Father,

5.verse: to whom be glory forever and ever. Amen.

6.verse: One Gospel, One Revelation, One Apostolate -Loyalty to the Gospel. -I am astonished that you are so quickly deserting the one who called you by the grace of Christ and are turning to a different gospel.

7.verse: In reality, there is not another one, but there are some who are troubling you by perverting the gospel of Christ.

8.verse: But even if we or an angel from heaven should preach a gospel to you other than the one we proclaimed to you, let him be accursed!

9.verse: We have said this before, and now I repeat it: if anyone preaches to you a gospel other than the one you received, let him be accursed!

10.verse: Does it now appear to you that I am trying to gain the approval of human beings rather than the approval of God? Am I seeking to please people? If I were still trying to please people, I would not be a servant of Christ.

11.verse: Paul’s Gospel Revealed to Him by Christ. -Brethren, I want you to be assured that the gospel I preached to you is not human in its origin.

12.verse: I did not receive it from a human being, nor was I taught it. Rather, I received it through a revelation of Jesus Christ.

13.verse: Undoubtedly you have heard about my former way of life in Judaism, how I fiercely persecuted the Church of God and tried to destroy it.

14.verse: I progressed in Judaism far beyond many of my contemporaries, inasmuch as I was much more zealous in upholding the traditions of my ancestors.

15.verse: Paul’s Early Years as a Christian. -However, when God, who had set me apart even before my birth, called me through his grace and chose

16.verse: to reveal his Son to me so that I might proclaim him to the Gentiles, I did not confer with flesh and blood,

17.verse: nor did I go up to Jerusalem to consult with those who were apostles before me. Rather, I went off to Arabia, and afterward I returned to Damascus.

18.verse: Paul’s First Meeting with Peter. -Then after three years, I did go up to Jerusalem to become acquainted with Cephas, and I stayed with him for fifteen days.

19.verse: However, I did not set eyes on any of the other apostles, except for James, the brother of the Lord.

20.verse: I declare before God that I am not lying in anything I have written.

21.verse: Afterward, I went into the regions of Syria and Cilicia.

22.verse: I was still unknown by sight to the Churches of Judea that are in Christ.

23.verse: They had only heard it said, “The one who was formerly persecuting us is now preaching the faith that he had once tried to destroy.”

24.verse: As a result, they gave glory to God because of me.

1.verse: Chapter 2 -The Council of Jerusalem -Confirmation of Paul’s Gospel and Mission. -Fourteen years later, I traveled up to Jerusalem again, this time with Barnabas, and I also took along Titus.

2.verse: I went up in response to a revelation, and I set before them the gospel that I preach to the Gentiles—in a private meeting with the leaders—to ensure that I was not running, or had not run, in vain.

3.verse: Yet not even Titus, who was accompanying me, was compelled to be circumcised, even though he was a Greek.

4.verse: Yet some false brethren were secretly brought in to spy on the freedom we have in Christ Jesus, so that they might reduce us to slavery.

5.verse: But not for a single moment did we submit to them, in order that the truth of the gospel might remain untouched for you.

6.verse: As for those who were regarded as men of importance—whether or not they actually were important makes no difference to me, nor does it matter to God—these men did not add anything further to my message.

7.verse: On the contrary, they realized that I had been entrusted with preaching the gospel to the uncircumcised, just as Peter had been entrusted with preaching the gospel to the circumcised (

8.verse: for the one who worked through Peter in his mission to the Jews was also at work in me in my mission to the Gentiles).

9.verse: Therefore, when James and Cephas and John, who were acknowledged as pillars of the community, recognized the grace that had been bestowed upon me, they gave to Barnabas and me the right hand of fellowship, agreeing that we should go to the Gentiles while they concentrated on the Jews.

10.verse: They asked only one thing: that we remember the poor, which is the very thing I was eager to do.

11.verse: Paul Rebukes Peter -Peter’s Inconsistency at Antioch. -However, when Cephas came to Antioch, I opposed him to his face, because he was in the wrong.

12.verse: For until some people came from James, he had been eating with the Gentiles; but when they arrived, he drew back and kept himself apart because he was afraid of the circumcised.

13.verse: And the rest of the Jews carried out the same pretense that he did, so that even Barnabas was led astray by their pretense.

14.verse: Paul’s Rebuke. -But when I saw that their conduct was not in accordance with the truth of the gospel, I said to Peter in front of all of them, “You are a Jew, yet you are living like a Gentile and not like a Jew. How then can you require the Gentiles to live like Jews?”

15.verse: Paul Defends the Freedom of Christians -It Is Faith That Saves -Justified by Faith in Christ. -We ourselves are Jews by birth and not Gentile sinners,

16.verse: yet we know that a man is justified not by the works of the Law but through faith in Jesus Christ. So we too came to believe in Christ Jesus so that we might be justified by faith in him and not by the works of the Law, for no one will be justified by the works of the Law.

17.verse: But if, in seeking to be justified in Christ, we ourselves are found to be sinners, is Christ then a servant of sin? By no means!

18.verse: However, if I am now rebuilding what I previously tore down, then I prove myself to be a transgressor.

19.verse: For through the Law I died to the Law so that I might live to God.I have been crucified with Christ.

20.verse: And now it is no longer I who live, but it is Christ who lives in me. The life I live now in the flesh I live by faith in the Son of God who loved me and gave himself up for me.

21.verse: I do not set aside the grace of God, for if justification comes through the Law, then Christ died for nothing.

1.verse: Chapter 3 -The Christian Experience. -You foolish Galatians! Who has bewitched you? Before your very eyes Jesus Christ was clearly presented as crucified.

2.verse: I only wish you to tell me this: Did you receive the Spirit by observing the Law or by believing what you heard?

3.verse: How can you be so foolish? After having begun with the Spirit, are you now ending in the flesh?

4.verse: Is everything you have suffered to result in absolutely nothing—if indeed it was for nothing?

5.verse: Does God give you the Spirit and work mighty deeds among you because you have kept the Law or because you believed what you have heard?

6.verse: The Blessing of Abraham. -Thus Abraham believed in God, and it was credited to him as righteousness.

7.verse: You can be assured that those who have faith are children of Abraham.

8.verse: Because Scripture foresaw that God would justify the Gentiles by faith, it declared the gospel beforehand to Abraham, saying, “In you all the nations will be blessed.”

9.verse: For this reason, those who have faith share the blessing with Abraham, the faithful one.

10.verse: The Curse of the Law. -In contrast, those who rely on the works of the Law are under a curse, for it is written “Cursed is everyone who does not persevere in doing all the things that are written in the book of the Law.”

11.verse: Now it is evident that no one is justified before God by the Law, for the one who is righteous will live by faith.

12.verse: However, the Law is not based on faith. On the contrary, whoever does these things shall live by them.

13.verse: Christ redeemed us from the curse of the Law by becoming a curse himself for us, as it is written, “Cursed is everyone who is hung upon a tree.”

14.verse: This is so that the blessing bestowed upon Abraham might be extended to the Gentiles through Jesus Christ so that we might receive the promise of the Spirit through faith.

15.verse: The Promise of the Covenant. -Brethren, allow me to give you an everyday example. Once a human will has been ratified, no one can make further additions to it or set it aside.

16.verse: Now the promises were made to Abraham and his descendant. It does not say “and to your descendants,” as referring to many, but it says “and to your descendant,” that is, to one person, who is Christ.

17.verse: This is what I am saying: the Law, which came four hundred and thirty years later, cannot invalidate a covenant that had been previously ratified by God, so as to nullify the promise.

18.verse: Obviously, if the inheritance comes from the Law, it no longer comes from the promise. However, God bestowed it on Abraham through a promise.

19.verse: The Purpose of the Law. -Why then? It was added because of transgressions until the descendant appeared to whom the promise had been made, and it was promulgated by angels through an intermediary.

20.verse: Now an intermediary is not necessary when there is only one party, and God is one.

21.verse: Is the Law then opposed to the promises of God? Absolutely not! If the Law that had been given had the power to bestow life, then righteousness would have come through the Law.

22.verse: But according to Scripture all things have been confined under sin, so that through faith in Jesus Christ what was promised might be given to those who believe.

23.verse: The Benefit of Faith. -Now before faith came, we were prisoners of the Law, confined as we waited for the faith that would eventually be revealed.

24.verse: Therefore, the Law was our tutor to bring us to Christ, so that we might be justified by faith.

25.verse: However, now that faith has come, we are no longer under a tutor.

26.verse: Children of God in Christ. -Through faith you are all children of God in Christ Jesus.

27.verse: For all of you who were baptized into Christ have clothed yourselves in Christ.

28.verse: There is no longer Jew or Greek, there is no longer slave or free man, there is no longer male or female. For all of you are one in Christ Jesus.

29.verse: And if you are Christ’s, then you are the offspring of Abraham and heirs according to the promise.

1.verse: Chapter 4 -Set Free by Christ. -What I am saying is that as long as an heir is a minor, he is no different from a slave, even though he is the owner of it all.

2.verse: He remains under the supervision of guardians and trustees until the date designated by the father.

3.verse: This is also true of us. As long as we were children, we were enslaved to the forces of this world.

4.verse: However, when the fullness of time had come, God sent his Son, born of a woman, born under the Law,

5.verse: in order to redeem those who were under the Law, so that we might receive adoption as sons.

6.verse: And because you are sons, God has sent into our hearts the Spirit of his Son, crying out “Abba! Father!”

7.verse: Therefore, you are no longer a slave but a son; and if you are a son, then through God you are also an heir.

8.verse: No Return to Slavery. -Previously, when you did not know God, you were slaves to forces who were not really gods at all.

9.verse: But now that you have come to know God—or rather to be known by God—how can you turn back once again to those powerless and destitute forces? How can you consider becoming enslaved once again?

10.verse: You even observe special days and months and seasons and years.

11.verse: Now I am afraid for you, that I have labored among you in vain.

12.verse: Appeal To Enter into Freedom from the Law. -I beg you, brethren, to be like me, just as I have become like you. You never did me any wrong.

13.verse: As you remember, it was because of illness that I originally preached the gospel to you.

14.verse: And though my illness was a trial to you, it did not lead to any scorn or revulsion; rather, you welcomed me as an angel of God, as if I were Christ Jesus himself.

15.verse: What has become of your blessedness? For I can testify that, if it had been possible, you would have plucked out your eyes and given them to me.

16.verse: Have I now become your enemy because I have told you the truth?

17.verse: Others are seeking to curry your favor, but they are not sincere. They are attempting to alienate you from us so that you may make them the sole object of your attention.

18.verse: It is good to be made much of for a good purpose at all times, and not just when I am in your presence.

19.verse: You are my children, and I am experiencing the pain of giving birth to you all over again, until Christ is formed in you.

20.verse: I truly wish that I could be with you now and be able to alter my approach to you, because I do not know what to think about you.

21.verse: Sarah and Hagar Foreshadow the Two Covenants. -And so tell me, you who are so eager to be subject to the Law: why do you not listen to the Law?

22.verse: For it is written that Abraham had two sons, one by a slave woman and one by a free woman.

23.verse: The son by the slave woman was born through the flesh. The son by the free woman was born through a promise.

24.verse: Now this is an allegory. These women represent two covenants. One covenant is given on Mount Sinai and bears children who are born into slavery; this is Hagar.

25.verse: Hagar stands for Sinai, a mountain in Arabia, and corresponds to the present city of Jerusalem, for she is in slavery together with her children.

26.verse: However, the Jerusalem that is above is the free woman, and she is our mother.

27.verse: For it is written,“Rejoice, you barren womanwho never bore a child;break forth in song and shout with joy,you who never were in labor.For more numerous are the children of the deserted wifethan the children of the one who has a husband.”

28.verse: Now you, brethren, are, like Isaac, the children of the promise.

29.verse: But just as in those days the child who was born through the flesh persecuted the child who was born through the Spirit, so is it now also.

30.verse: However, what does Scripture say?“Drive out the slave woman and her son!For the son of the slave woman shall not share the inheritancewith the son of the free woman.”

31.verse: Therefore, brethren, we are the children not of the slave woman but of the free woman.

1.verse: There Is No Freedom Except in Christ -Chapter 5 -Faith Expressing Itself through Love. -It was for freedom that Christ set us free. Therefore, stand firm and refuse to submit again to the yoke of slavery.

2.verse: Listen to me! I, Paul, tell you that if you allow yourselves to be circumcised, Christ will be of no value to you.

3.verse: Once again, I testify that every man who accepts circumcision is under obligation to observe the entire Law.

4.verse: Those of you who seek to be justified by the Law have cut yourselves off from Christ and have fallen away from grace.

5.verse: For it is through the Spirit and by faith that we eagerly hope to attain righteousness,

6.verse: since in Christ Jesus neither circumcision nor lack of circumcision is worth anything. All that matters is faith expressing itself through love.

7.verse: Against Being Misled. -You were running a good race. Who kept you from obeying the truth?

8.verse: This change did not come from the one who called you.

9.verse: A little yeast leavens the entire batch of dough.

10.verse: I am confident of you in the Lord that none of you will think differently, and that anyone who is trying to confuse you will be condemned, no matter who it is.

11.verse: As for me, brethren, if I were still advocating circumcision, why would I continue to be persecuted? If I were doing that, the cross would no longer be a stumbling block.

12.verse: I wish that those who are confusing you would even castrate themselves!

13.verse: Proper Use of Freedom. -Brethren, you were called to freedom. However, make sure that you do not use your freedom as an opportunity for the flesh. Instead, serve one another in love.

14.verse: For the entire Law can be summed up in a single commandment: “You shall love your neighbor as yourself.”

15.verse: But if you continue biting and tearing one another to pieces, at least be on your guard lest you be consumed by one another.

16.verse: Hence, I advise you to be guided by the Spirit, so that you will not gratify the desires of the flesh.

17.verse: For the desires of the flesh are opposed to the Spirit, and those of the Spirit are opposed to the flesh. They are in conflict with one another, so that you cannot do what you want.

18.verse: But if you are guided by the Spirit, you are not subject to the Law.

19.verse: Now the works of the flesh are obvious: fornication, impurity, licentiousness,

20.verse: idolatry, sorcery, enmities, strife, jealousy, anger, quarrels, dissensions, factions,

21.verse: envy, drunkenness, carousing, and the like. I warn you, as I warned you previously, that no one who does such things will inherit the kingdom of God.

22.verse: In contrast, the fruit of the Spirit is love, joy, peace, patience, kindness, generosity, faithfulness,

23.verse: gentleness, and self-control. There is no law against such things.

24.verse: And those who belong to Christ Jesus have crucified the flesh with its passions and desires.

25.verse: If we live by the Spirit, let us also be guided by the Spirit.

26.verse: We should not become conceited, or provoke one another, or be envious of one another.

1.verse: Chapter 6 -The Law of Christ. -Brethren, if anyone is detected committing a transgression, you who are spiritual must set him right in a spirit of gentleness. Meanwhile, you should take care so that you yourselves are not tempted.

2.verse: Bear one another’s burdens, and in this way you will fulfill the law of Christ.

3.verse: If anyone thinks he is something when in fact he is nothing, he is only deceiving himself.

4.verse: Each person must examine his own work. Then he will have reason to boast with regard to himself alone and not in comparison with someone else.

5.verse: For everyone has his own burden to bear.

6.verse: Anyone who is being taught should give his teacher a share in all his possessions.

7.verse: Do not be deceived; God cannot be mocked. A person will reap only what he sows.

8.verse: The one who sows in his flesh will reap a harvest of corruption, but the one who sows in the Spirit will reap from the Spirit the reward of eternal life.

9.verse: Let us never grow weary in doing what is right, for if we do not give up, we will reap our harvest in due time.

10.verse: Therefore, while we have the opportunity, let us labor for the good of all, but especially for those members of the household of the faith.

11.verse: Conclusion -The Cross of Christ, Our True Boast. -Observe what large letters I make when I am writing to you in my own handwriting.

12.verse: It is those who want to gain human approval who are trying to compel you to be circumcised, their sole purpose being to escape persecution for the cross of Christ.

13.verse: Even the circumcised do not themselves obey the Law. They want you to be circumcised so that they may boast in your flesh.

14.verse: May I never boast of anything except the cross of our Lord Jesus Christ, through which the world is crucified to me and I to the world.

15.verse: Neither circumcision nor uncircumcision is important, but only a new creation.

16.verse: Blessing and a Plea. -May peace and mercy be given to all who follow this rule, and to the Israel of God.

17.verse: In the future, let no one make trouble for me, for I bear the marks of Jesus branded on my body.

18.verse: May the grace of our Lord Jesus Christ be with your spirit, brethren. Amen.
